For Release Saturday, Dec. 30
Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Saturday, Dec. 30, the 364th day of 1989. There is one day left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On Dec. 30, 1853, the United States bought some 45,000 square miles of land from Mexico in a deal that became known as the Gadsden Purchase, for the man who engineered it, James Gadsden. The area became the southern part of Arizona and New Mexico. On this date: In 1865, author Rudyard Kipling was born in Bombay, India. In 1894, suffragist Amelia Jenks Bloomer died. She had gained notoriety for wearing in public a short skirt and baggy trousers that became known as ``bloomers.'' In 1903, about 600 people died when fire broke out at the Iroquois Theater in Chicago. In 1911, Sun Yat-sen was elected the first president of the Republic of China after the fall of the Chinese dynasties. In 1936, the United Auto Workers union staged its first ``sit-down'' strike, at the Fisher Body Plant No. 1 in Flint, Mich. In 1944, King George II of Greece proclaimed a regency to rule his country, virtually renouncing the throne. In 1947, King Michael of Romania agreed to abdicate, but charged he was being forced off the throne by communists. In 1972, the United States halted its heavy bombing of North Vietnam. In 1977, President Carter held the first news conference by an American president in Eastern Europe as he told reporters in Warsaw that both Americans and Poles shared the same aspiration for ``complete preservation and enhancement of human rights.'' In 1978, Ohio State University fired Woody Hayes as football coach, one day after Hayes punched Clemson University player Charlie Bauman during the Gator Bowl after Bauman intercepted an Ohio pass. Ten years ago: Broadway composer Richard Rodgers, who had written the scores for such classics of American theater as ``Pal Joey,'' ``Oklahoma!'' and ``South Pacific,'' died in New York at age 77. Five years ago: The Madhya Pradesh state government in India announced it was filing suit in U.S. courts against Union Carbide following the leak of poison gas at a plant in Bhopal that killed more than 3,500 people. One year ago: President Reagan and President-elect Bush were subpoenaed to testify as defense witnesses in the pending Iran-Contra trial of Oliver North. The subpoenas were subsequently quashed. Today's Birthdays: Actress Jeanette Nolan is 78. TV personality Bert Parks is 75. Actress Jo Van Fleet is 70. Singer Bo Diddley is 61. Actor Jack Lord is 59. Actor John Hillerman is 57. Baseball hall-of-famer Sandy Koufax is 54. Singer-songwriter Del Shannon is 50. Singer-musician Michael Nesmith is 47. Singer-actress Tracey Ullman is 30. Runner Ben Johnson is 28. Thought for Today: ``Work is a dull thing; you cannot get away from that. The only agreeable existence is one of idleness, and that is not, unfortunately, always compatible with continuing to exist at all.'' _ Rose Macaulay, English poet and essayist (1881-1958).
